title: Other Types of Vehicle: Share the Road Confidently
summary: Learn how to anticipate the behaviour and limitations of buses, lorries, trams, and slow-moving vehicles.

sections.title: Why Other Vehicles Matter
sections.body: Large or specialist vehicles have different speeds, turning circles, and blind spots. Understanding them keeps you safe and professional when sharing the road.

sections.title: DVSA Essentials
items: Give large vehicles extra room when they swing out to turn left—they need space to clear kerbs.
Never pass a tram on the inside unless directed; follow lane signals and obey dedicated traffic lights.
Farm vehicles or mobility scooters may travel well below the limit—be patient and only overtake when it’s legal, safe, and necessary.

sections.title: Vehicle Characteristics
items: Buses and coaches: watch for signals indicating they’re pulling out from stops—give priority when you can do so safely.
Heavy goods vehicles: longer stopping distances, large blind spots, and spray in wet weather.
Trams: follow road markings and signals; remember they cannot steer to avoid you.
Slow-moving vehicles: tractors, road sweepers, and gritters often travel at 25 mph or less and may turn suddenly into fields or side roads.

sections.title: Planning Overtakes
sections.body: Check far ahead before overtaking large vehicles. You need a long, clear view, ample acceleration space, and time to move back without cutting in. If in doubt, hold back—arriving safely matters more than saving seconds.

sections.title: Night and Weather Considerations
items: Expect extra spray and turbulence when passing lorries in rain—use wipers and keep both hands on the wheel.
At night, dip headlights early to avoid dazzling lorry drivers sitting higher up.
When following a snow plough or gritter, stay well back and be prepared for sudden stops.

checklist.label: I know where large vehicle blind spots are and avoid lingering in them.
I anticipate buses pulling away from stops and plan to help them rejoin safely.
I only overtake slow vehicles when I can complete the manoeuvre smoothly and legally.
I obey tram signals and road markings, treating the rails as a separate lane.

practiceTips.label: Mirror map
practiceTips.detail: Sketch the blind spots of a lorry from a DVSA diagram. Keep it in your notes to remind you where to position your car.

practiceTips.label: Theo’s bus drill
practiceTips.detail: When you see a bus signal, count ‘mirror, signal, gap, go’. Even if you can’t let it out, the routine keeps your planning sharp.

practiceTips.label: Overtake reflections
practiceTips.detail: After each drive, note any times you chose not to overtake. Praising patient decisions builds confidence in waiting.

questions.prompt: Why do large vehicles sometimes move to the right before turning left?

options.label: To confuse following drivers
options.explanation: They need extra room, not to confuse traffic.

options.label: To position for a wide turn and avoid clipping the kerb
options.explanation: Give them space; do not try to squeeze between the vehicle and the kerb.

options.label: Because the driver is unsure where to turn
options.explanation: Professional drivers plan turns carefully—the movement is deliberate.

options.label: To let you undertake them on the left
options.explanation: Never pass between a large vehicle and the kerb; they may swing back in.

questions.prompt: You are following a tractor on a country road. When is it safe to overtake?

options.label: Immediately, because tractors must pull over
options.explanation: Tractors are not obliged to pull over instantly—you must wait for a safe gap.

options.label: When you have a clear view of the road ahead and it’s legal to overtake
options.explanation: Only pass if you can complete the manoeuvre without exceeding the speed limit or crossing solid lines.

options.label: When the tractor slows at any junction
options.explanation: They may be turning—overtaking here is dangerous.

options.label: Whenever oncoming traffic flashes to let you pass
options.explanation: Only overtake with a clear view; never rely solely on another driver’s signal.

questions.prompt: What should you do if a bus is signalling to leave a stop?

options.label: Maintain speed and pass as quickly as possible
options.explanation: This can trap the bus and increase risk for passengers.

options.label: Slow down and let the bus out if it’s safe
options.explanation: Helping buses rejoin supports traffic flow and is encouraged by the Highway Code.

options.label: Sound your horn so the bus knows you’re there
options.explanation: Use the horn only to warn of danger.

options.label: Overtake on the left before it pulls away
options.explanation: Undertaking a bus at a stop is risky—passengers may step out and the bus may move off.

questions.prompt: How should you approach a level crossing used by trams?

options.label: Ignore tram signals because they don’t apply to cars
options.explanation: Tram signals must be obeyed—they control movement across the tracks.

options.label: Follow the dedicated signals and road markings, crossing only when they show it’s safe
options.explanation: Trams cannot steer around you, so you must follow their signals exactly.

options.label: Stop on the tracks to check for trams
options.explanation: Never stop on the rails—you must ensure your exit is clear before crossing.

options.label: Accelerate quickly to clear the crossing regardless of signals
options.explanation: Ignoring tram signals can put you directly in the path of an approaching tram.

questions.prompt: You approach a large vehicle displaying flashing amber beacons on a dual carriageway. What should you do?

options.label: Slow down, keep well back, and follow any instructions or road signs
options.explanation: Amber beacons warn of a slow-moving or stationary vehicle—give it plenty of room.

options.label: Overtake immediately on whichever side has space
options.explanation: You may encounter workers or debris—wait until it’s clearly safe and legal to pass.

options.label: Sound the horn repeatedly so they know you’re behind
options.explanation: Use the horn only if there’s danger—not to hurry other road users.

options.label: Flash your headlights to make them move over
options.explanation: Flashing may dazzle the driver and won’t change their need for extra space.
